ENGRCEE 295P.course_description: Studies in selected areas of Civil and Environmental Engineering. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

ENGRCEE 296.course_description: Individual research or investigation conducted in preparation of the thesis required for the M.S. degree in Engineering.

ENGRCEE 297.course_description: Individual research or investigation conducted in preparation for the dissertation required for the Ph.D. degree in Engineering.

ENGRCEE 298.course_name: Special Topics in Civil and Environmental Engineering
ENGRCEE 298.course_description: Presentation of advanced topics and special research areas in civil and environmental engineering.

ENGRCEE 299.course_description: Individual research or investigation under the direction of an individual faculty member.

CLT&THY 200A.course_description: Introduction to canonical texts in Marxism coupled with an examination of the questions of race, gender, ethnicity, and sexuality that distend the calculus of the canon’s assumptive logic. May be taken after CLT&THY 200B.

CLT&THY 200B.course_description: Introduction to canonical texts in psychoanalysis coupled with an examination of the questions of race, gender, ethnicity, and sexuality that distend the calculus of the canon’s assumptive logic. May be taken before CLT&THY 200A.

CLT&THY 200C.course_description: Introduction to systems of thought understudied or undervalued in academic canons; for instance, systems constituted in communities' practices or theories that do not seek permanence or generality.

CLT&THY 241.course_name: Ethics, Erotics, and Will: Gendered Black Politics, Sexualized Racisms, and the Humanities
CLT&THY 241.course_description: Introduces doctoral students to an interdisciplinary conversation about black queer sexuality and black heteropatriarchy. Uses disciplinary formations as a tool for understanding knowledge formations about the shifting relations that constitute sexuality, gender, and racial blackness.

CLT&THY 242.course_name: Afro-Pessimism and the Status of the Subject
CLT&THY 242.course_description: Afro-Pessimism theorizes the Black as a being against which all other beings become legible as human subjects. Focuses on either the subject of psychoanalysis or the subject of capital accumulation in their explorations of the antagonism between Blackness.

CLT&THY 280.course_description: Limited to students who have not yet received the M.A. degree.

CLT&THY 289.course_description: Seminars on various topics in Culture and Theory.

CLT&THY 298.course_description: Directed readings on a specific topic agreed upon by students and their instructors. Limited to students who have completed their M.A. degree and are preparing for their qualifying exam.

CLT&THY 299.course_description: Dissertation research in Culture and Theory.

FRENCH 1A.course_description: First quarter of first-year French in a hybrid format. Students are taught to conceptualize in French as they learn to understand, read, write, and speak. Classes are conducted entirely in French.

FRENCH 1AB.course_description: Intensive first half of first-year French. Students are taught to conceptualize in French as they learn to read, write, and speak. Students develop an awareness of and sensibility to French and Francophone life and culture through reading, viewing, and discussion.

FRENCH 1ABSP.course_name: Accelerated Fundamentals of French for Spanish Speakers
FRENCH 1ABSP.course_description: Accelerated first half of first-year French for Hispanophone students. Teaches conceptualizing in French while learning to read, write, and speak using knowledge of Spanish. Develops awareness of and sensibility to French and Francophone life and culture through reading, viewing, discussing.

FRENCH 1B.course_description: Second quarter of first-year French in a hybrid format. Students are taught to conceptualize in French as they learn to understand, read, write, and speak. Classes are conducted entirely in French.

FRENCH 1BC.course_description: Intensive second half of first-year French. Students are taught to conceptualize in French as they learn to read, write, and speak. Students develop an awareness of and sensibility to French and Francophone life and culture through reading, viewing, and discussion.

FRENCH 1BCSP.course_name: Accelerated Fundamentals of French for Spanish Speakers
FRENCH 1BCSP.course_description: Accelerated second half of first-year French for Hispanophone students. Teaches conceptualizing in French while learning to read, write, and speak using knowledge of Spanish. Develops awareness of and sensibility to French and Francophone life and culture through reading, viewing, discussing.

FRENCH 1C.course_description: Third quarter of first-year French in a hybrid format. Students are taught to conceptualize in French as they learn to understand, read, write, and speak. Classes are conducted entirely in French.

FRENCH S1AB.course_description: First half of first-year French in an intensified form. Students are taught to conceptualize in French as they learn to understand, read, write, and speak. Classes are conducted entirely in French.

FRENCH S1BC.course_description: Second half of first-year French in an intensified form. Students are taught to conceptualize in French as they learn to understand, read, write, and speak. Classes are conducted entirely in French.

FRENCH 2A.course_description: Second-year French in a hybrid format. Students are taught to conceptualize in French as they learn to understand, read, write, and speak. Classes are conducted entirely in French.

FRENCH 2AB.course_description: Intensive first half of second-year French. Texts and films of contemporary literary or social interest provide the focus for more advanced conversation, reading, and composition. Classes are conducted entirely in French.

FRENCH 2B.course_description: Second-year French in a hybrid format. Students are taught to conceptualize in French as they learn to understand, read, write, and speak. Classes are conducted entirely in French.

FRENCH 2BC.course_description: Intensive second half of second-year French. Texts and films of contemporary literary or social interest provide the focus for more advanced conversation, reading, and composition. Classes are conducted entirely in French.

FRENCH 2C.course_description: Second-year French in a hybrid format. Students are taught to conceptualize in French as they learn to understand, read, write, and speak. Classes are conducted entirely in French.

FRENCH S2AB.course_description: First half/second half of second-year French in an intensified form. Students are taught to conceptualize in French as they learn to understand, read, write, and speak. Classes are conducted entirely in French.

FRENCH S2BC.course_description: First half/second half of second-year French in an intensified form. Students are taught to conceptualize in French as they learn to understand, read, write, and speak. Classes are conducted entirely in French.

FRENCH 10.course_description: Tutoring Program in which advanced French students provide assistance to students at a lower level. One hour of tutoring per week.

FRENCH 50.course_name: Topics in French Culture and the Modern World
FRENCH 50.course_description: Introductory course for non-majors. Focuses on France's role in the modern world and its cultural connections to Asia, the Middle East, Africa, Europe, and the Americas. Taught in English.

FRENCH 97.course_name: Fundamentals of French (with Emphasis on Reading)
FRENCH 97.course_description: Designed primarily for students interested in acquiring a solid reading knowledge of French, and to facilitate the understanding and translating of French texts dealing with a variety of disciplines.

FRENCH 101B.course_description: Literature and philosophy of the 18th century studied in relationship to a specific literary or historical problem.

FRENCH 101C.course_description: Literatures of the French-speaking world studied in relationship to a specific literary or historical problem.

FRENCH 102A.course_description: Review of grammar taught in FRENCH 2A-B-C. Students gain facility in writing French and increase reading comprehension. Short texts and films are introduced to generate substantive discussion, and multiple short writing exercises are assigned to solidify skills. Formerly FRENCH 60.

FRENCH 102B.course_name: Topics in Issues in French and Francophone Culture
FRENCH 102B.course_description: Investigation of an issue of cultural significance in the francophone world through historical documents, literary works, and newspaper articles. Supplemented with films and/or other elements of popular culture. Multiple short writing assignments to solidify writing skills. Formerly FRENCH 61.

FRENCH 102C.course_description: Introduction to the theory and practice of translation from French to English and English to French. Many opportunities provided to improve skills in writing and comprehension. Formerly FRENCH 62.

FRENCH 102D.course_name: Topics in the Work World in French
FRENCH 102D.course_description: A view into the world of work in French. Areas of study include international relations; French administration; and tensions between management and workers. Attention given to vocabulary and grammar of professional interactions in French. Formerly FRENCH 63.

FRENCH 102E.course_description: Intended for advanced students who wish to improve their expressive capabilities in French. Review of more nuanced grammar points. Emphasis placed on rhetoric, syntax, and precision. Advanced readings increase comprehension. Formerly FRENCH 64.

FRENCH 116.course_description: Examines the diverse literature of the Renaissance and the Age of Exploration.

FRENCH 117.course_description: Examines the age of drama and other vibrant forms in French literature of the period.

FRENCH 118.course_description: Examines the literature and philosophy of the Enlightenment, the Ancient Régime, Classicism, and/or Revolution.

FRENCH 119.course_description: Focuses on the literature of an era that experienced many modernist transformations.

FRENCH 120.course_name: Topics in 20th-Century French and Francophone Literature
FRENCH 120.course_description: A study of modern and contemporary literature and culture.

FRENCH 127.course_name: Topics in Francophone Literature and Culture
FRENCH 127.course_description: Literature and cultures of the francophone world.

FRENCH 139W.course_description: In English. Readings of masterpieces of French literature in their social, political, and historical contexts. Requires at least 4,000 words of assigned composition based on French works. Several essays required.

FRENCH 140.course_description: Examines the development and transformation of a single genre, such as the poem or the novel.

FRENCH 150.course_name: Topics in French Literature and Culture
FRENCH 150.course_description: Study of a theme, movement, or problem crucial to understanding French Literature and Culture.

FRENCH 160.course_description: Study of a period, movement, or theme in French or Francophone cinema.

FRENCH 170.course_description: Examines the dialogue between historical events and literary texts.

FRENCH 171.course_description: Examines the role played by politics and ethics in French literature, film, and culture.

FRENCH 180.course_description: Advanced study of theoretical and critical texts.

FRENCH 199.course_description: A project proposal is prepared by the student and approved by the faculty member who directs the project. Procedure must be completed by the end of the first week of classes.

FRENCH 218.course_description: Advanced study of a topic in the 18th century.

FRENCH 250.course_description: Advanced study of a topic in theory and/or criticism.

FRENCH 290.course_name: Research in French Language and Literature
FRENCH 290.course_description: A project proposal is prepared by the student and approved by the faculty member who directs the project. Procedure must be completed by the end of the first week of classes.  Limit: Once for M.A. candidates; twice for Ph.D. candidates.

FRENCH 299.course_description: For graduate students writing a dissertation with a faculty member in French.

FRENCH 399.course_description: For graduate students completing a course on foreign language pedagogy.

EPIDEM 199.course_description: Provides disciplinary research participation. Original or existing research options provide undergraduates the opportunity for faculty/mentor interactions including access to appropriate facilities. Medical Epidemiology research areas: Cancer, Genetic/Molecular, Environmental, Occupational, Biostatistics, and Infectious Disease.

EPIDEM 200A.course_description: Fundamental principles of epidemiology, biostatistics, and epidemiological research. Topics include research methods of measuring health problems in populations, disease control and prevention in populations, how epidemiology contributes to knowledge of disease etiology, and biostatistical analysis and interpretation of epidemiologic data.

EPIDEM 200B.course_description: Learn to design and conduct epidemiologic studies using common designs. Determine why bias and measurement error arise in observational studies, and how they influence effect estimates. Perform and interpret epidemiologic data analyses using statistical software.

EPIDEM 200C.course_description: Advanced topics in the design and statistical analysis of epidemiologic studies. Topics include simulation methods, counter-matching and multiphase study designs, missing data, and Bayesian analysis. Published simulation studies are discussed and replicated using the R software package.

EPIDEM 201.course_description: Concentrates on understanding how epidemiology plays a role in the search for cancer etiology, prevention, control, and treatment; gives an overview of cancer research with an appreciation of the multidisciplinary nature of the field.

EPIDEM 202.course_description: Concentrates on the role of genetic factors in the etiology of disease in human populations with an objective of disease control and prevention and the role of interactions of genetic factors and environmental exposures in the occurrence of disease.

EPIDEM 204A.course_name: Biostatistics I: Introduction to Statistical Methods
EPIDEM 204A.course_description: Designed to help students develop an appreciation for statistician's view of the research process, emphasizing biomedical research. Instills an understanding of how statistical models are used to yield insights about data that form evidence-based understanding of the world around us.

EPIDEM 204B.course_description: Intended for graduate students in epidemiology, public health, and clinical research fields. Covers common regression-modeling techniques frequently used in biologic and medical applications.

EPIDEM 204C.course_description: Intended for graduate students in epidemiology, public health, and related fields.  Introduces statistical methods for analyzing survival and longitudinal/clustered data, and techniques to resolve missing data.

EPIDEM 205.course_description: Concentrates on epidemiological approaches to the assessment of community environmental hazards; issues involved in environmental exposure estimation; interdisciplinary approaches to environmental epidemiology, including the use of biomarkers of exposures and susceptibility; epidemiological studies within the context of risk assessment.

EPIDEM 212.course_name: Methods for Design and Implementation of Epidemiologic Research
EPIDEM 212.course_description: Intended for students in epidemiology, public health, and related fields, and covers topics in subject recruitment, data collection, quality assessment and control, and sample-size estimation.

EPIDEM 215.course_description: Provides students with knowledge of the basic principles, concepts, and methods used in statistical genetic research. Topics include principles of population genetics, and statistical methods for family- and population-based studies.

EPIDEM 232.course_description: Epidemiological aspects of chronic human diseases. Topics include methodologies for quantifying aspects of prevalent chronic diseases including risk factors, identification of susceptible groups, societal burdens, promising future research; and the intervention, prevention, and control of diseases in populations.

EPIDEM 244.course_description: Industrial ecology of toxicants and their impacts on environmental quality and human health. Explores theoretical basis of toxicity thresholds and regulatory issues. Uses classic and contemporary research articles to understand the legacy of traditional toxicants, and to identify emerging threats.

EPIDEM 264.course_description: Convergence of agents (chemical, physical, biological, or psychosocial) in environment can emerge as diseases influenced by social, political, and economic factors, allowing them to become rooted in society. How these agents from various spheres come together and impact human health.

EPIDEM 269.course_description: Emission of air pollutants into the atmosphere, physical and meteorological processes that affect transport, and influence on global warming. Concepts of how and where people are most exposed, and how exposures and health effects differ in developed and developing regions.

EPIDEM 275.course_description: Presents various topics and latest research in the broad field of epidemiology.

EPIDEM 280.course_description: Research journal club is a group discussion of recent publications in epidemiology and related fields.  Students rotate as lead discussants, guided by faculty.  All attendees are expected to be familiar with the papers at the start of class.

EPIDEM 282.course_description: A forum for the presentation of recent research to epidemiology students, faculty, and other interested parties. The atmosphere is informal, yet rigorous. Speakers range from graduate students through distinguished visitors from other institutions.

EPIDEM 290.course_name: Introduction to Biostatistics and Epidemiology for Medical Fellows
EPIDEM 290.course_description: Prepares medical fellows and other physicians for rotations in research programs. Understanding of basic biostatistics and study design, and interdependencies between the two. Application of principles in evaluation of medical literature for guidance on patient care and public health policy.

EPIDEM 296.course_description: Individual research and study necessary for a graduate student to prepare and complete the thesis required for the Master of Science (M.S.) degree.

EPIDEM 297.course_description: Individual research and study necessary for a graduate student to prepare and complete the dissertation required for the Doctor of Philosophy (Ph.D.) degree.

EPIDEM 399.course_description: Limited to students with active Teaching Assistant (T.A.) appointments.

CLASSIC 10.course_description: A study of English terms derived from Greek and Latin and important to contemporary medicine, science, and other professions, with emphasis on development of word-building skills. No prior knowledge of Greek or Latin required.

CLASSIC 36A.course_name: The Formation of Ancient Greek Society: Early Greece
CLASSIC 36A.course_description: A survey of ancient Greek civilization from its origins in the Bronze Age to the mid-Archaic period. Examines political and social history, as well as literature, art, religion, and archaeological remains.

CLASSIC 36B.course_name: The Formation of Ancient Greek Society:  Late Archaic and Classical Greece
CLASSIC 36B.course_description: A survey of ancient Greek civilization from the Late Archaic period to the Classical period. Focuses on major institutions and cultural phenomena as seen through the study of ancient Greek literature, history, archaeology, and religion.

CLASSIC 36C.course_name: The Formation of Ancient Greek Society: Fourth-Century and Hellenistic Greece
CLASSIC 36C.course_description: A survey of ancient Greek civilization from the fourth century BCE through to the Hellenistic period. Focuses on major institutions and cultural phenomena as seen through the study of ancient Greek literature, history, archaeology, and religion.

CLASSIC 37A.course_name: The Formation of Ancient Roman Society: Origins to Roman Republic
CLASSIC 37A.course_description: A survey of the development of Roman civilization from its eighth century BCE beginnings to the civil wars of the first century BCE. Examines political and social history, as well as literature, art, architecture, and religion.

CLASSIC 37B.course_name: The Formation of Ancient Roman Society: Roman Empire
CLASSIC 37B.course_description: A survey of Roman civilization from Augustus’s consolidation of power following the civil wars of the first century BCE to the crisis of the third century CE. Includes social history, literature, art, architecture, and religion.

CLASSIC 37C.course_name: The Formation of Ancient Roman Society: The Fall of Rome
CLASSIC 37C.course_description: A survey of Roman civilization from the crisis of the third century CE to the so-called “fall of Rome” in 476 CE.  Examines political and social history, as well as literature, art, architecture, and religion.

CLASSIC 45A.course_description: An overview of the main myths of the gods of the ancient Greeks and Romans and their influence in contemporary and later literature and art. Includes readings from both ancient and modern sources.

CLASSIC 45B.course_description: An overview of the main myths of the heroes of the ancient Greeks and Romans and their influence in contemporary and later literature and art. Includes readings from both ancient and modern sources.

CLASSIC 45C.course_name: Classical Mythology: Ancient and Modern Perspectives of Classical Mythology
CLASSIC 45C.course_description: Detailed examination of key Greek and Roman myths, their interpretations, and the influence they have exerted on literature, art, and popular culture in subsequent periods.

CLASSIC 99.course_description: Lower-division level independent research with Classics faculty.

CLASSIC 140.course_name: Classics and History: The Ancient World
CLASSIC 140.course_description: Selected topics in society and culture of the Graeco-Roman world. Readings in translation.

CLASSIC 150.course_description: Selected myths and legends as used in Classical literature, and their modern interpretations.

CLASSIC 160.course_name: Topics in Classical Literature in English Translation
CLASSIC 160.course_description: Studies in selected areas of Classical literature. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

CLASSIC 160W.course_name: Topics in Classical Literature in English Translation
CLASSIC 160W.course_description: Studies in selected areas of Classical literature. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

CLASSIC 166.course_description: Studies in selected areas of Classical reception. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

CLASSIC 170.course_description: Studies in selected areas of Classical civilization. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

CLASSIC 176.course_description: Develops a broader understanding of the formation of different cultures and countries of Classical times and their impact on the modern world.

CLASSIC 192A.course_description: Under the guidance of a faculty mentor, majors design and execute a senior project. This project may be a research paper, dramatic production, school curriculum, etc. All projects must be approved by the faculty mentor.

CLASSIC 192B.course_description: Under the guidance of a faculty mentor, majors design and execute a senior project. This project may be a research paper, dramatic production, school curriculum, etc. All projects must be approved by the faculty mentor.

CLASSIC 198.course_description: Special topics in Classical studies through directed reading and research.

MGMT EP 200.course_name: Thinking Strategically in the Digital Age for Executives
MGMT EP 200.course_description: Focuses on the strategic and organizational challenges that a rapidly changing environment poses to the firm’s management and frames them according to Merage’s strategic emphasis on analytical decision making, innovation, and information technology.

MGMT EP 201A.course_description: Methods of statistical inference, emphasizing applications to administrative and management decision problems. Topics include classical estimation, hypothesis testing, regression, correlation, analysis of variance, decision analysis, and forecasting.

MGMT EP 202.course_description: Develops a better understanding of individual and group behavior in and across organizations, and the frameworks by which to analyze and understand behavior in complex organizations. Enhances the skills required to manage collaboration and lead. Every other weekend course.

MGMT EP 203A.course_description: Involves the development, analysis, and interpretation of financial accounting information for external reporting purposes. Emphasis on measurement and valuation issues in decision-making problems and cases. Every other weekend course format.

MGMT EP 203B.course_description: Involves developing and using internal financial and non-financial information to help organizations make planning, budgeting, control, operating, and performance evaluation decisions. Every other weekend course format.

MGMT EP 204A.course_name: Microeconomics for Executives in the Digital Age
MGMT EP 204A.course_description: Provides basic tools for analyzing economic decisions of consumers and firms. Topics include demand and supply analysis, production and cost theory, perfect competition, monopoly, market failures, and introductory game theory.  Every other weekend course format.

MGMT EP 205.course_description: Introduction to marketing. Topics include developing familiarity with fundamental marketing concepts, theories, and techniques; acquainting students with the type of decisions made by executives, including customer targeting, product, pricing, place, promotion, and research. Every other weekend course format.

MGMT EP 207.course_name: Competing with Digital: Technology, Analytics, Business Models
MGMT EP 207.course_description: Focuses on how information technology is used to create value in organizations through product, process, and strategy innovation. Aims to help managers understand the strategic role of key information technologies in managing organizations. Every other weekend course format.

MGMT EP 208.course_name: Operational Excellence: Processes, Strategy, and Analytics
MGMT EP 208.course_description: Introduction to strategic and tactical issues in production and operations management. A blend of quantitative and qualitative considerations. Topics include product planning, process design, capacity management, production planning, inventory control, just-in-time manufacturing, and quality management. Every other weekend course format.

MGMT EP 209A.course_description: Introduces students to financial theory and concepts. Topics include time value of money, valuation of stocks and bonds, capital budgeting, portfolio theory, and capital structure choice. Every other weekend course format.

MGMT EP 210.course_name: Strategy for Executives: Foundations and Dynamics
MGMT EP 210.course_description: Provides conceptual frameworks and techniques to analyze and develop firm strategies. Through case analysis/discussion, helps improve strategic thinking by developing frameworks by which to assess, evaluate, and respond to different business situations. Every other weekend course format.

MGMT EP 219.course_name: Practice of General Management for Executives
MGMT EP 219.course_description: Teaches the graduating MBA how the best managers actually manage. Students develop a toolkit of proven concepts and practices that will help them succeed as managers at any level.

MGMT EP 225.course_description: Using a combination of theory and practice via negotiation simulations, students expand their repertoire of negotiating skills and develop their ability to analyze different negotiation situations and contexts. Every other weekend course format.

MGMT EP 290.course_description: Studies in selected areas of business. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

MGMT EP 295A.course_description: Fundamentals of global strategy, economics, and financial issues. Topics include global manager’s environment, global strategy, impact of national culture on business systems, strategies and practices, foreign direct investment, corporate governance, human resources, and international marketing. Every other weekend course format.

MGMT EP 295B.course_description: Emphasizes and reinforces international perspectives contained in the M.B.A. curriculum by providing a week-long intensive seminar abroad in the second year. Scholars and business people from the host country instruct Executive M.B.A. students in designed class sessions and company visits.

MGMT EP 296.course_description: Focuses on the conceptual, practical, and personal dimensions of executive leadership. Past and current leadership theories are addressed. Individual personal assessment and diagnosis. Every other weekend course format.

MGMT EP 299.course_description: Individual Study under the direction of a selected faculty member.

EHS 201.course_description: Analysis of real problems involving toxic chemicals and the human food, air, water supplies, occupational exposures, and lifestyles. Formal problems will be considered by small groups of students and discussed by the class.

EHS 202.course_description: Introduction to basic principles of toxicology. Absorption, distribution, metabolism, and excretion (ADME) of xenobiotics are covered and illustrated with specific examples.

EHS 203.course_description: Importance of psychosocial work environment for workers’ health and productivity has increased with changing technology, work organization, demographics, and occupation/industry structures. This advanced occupational epidemiology course focuses on psychosocial work environment as exposures, and workers’ health and productivity as outcomes.

EHS 204.course_description: The effects of various harmful chemicals upon nervous system function. Emphasis given to the molecular events underlying neurological damage and to the relation of such processes to basic mechanisms of neurobiology.

EHS 206A.course_description: Mechanistic analysis of responses occurring in various organ systems of experimental animals and humans exposed to environmental and occupational chemicals and radiation. Review distinctive cellular and tissue structure and physiological function of the various organ systems.

EHS 206B.course_description: Mechanistic analysis of responses occurring in various organ systems of experimental animals and humans exposed to environmental and occupational chemicals and radiation. Review of distinctive cellular and tissue structure and physiological function of the various organ systems.

EHS 207.course_name: Experimental Design and Interpretation of Toxicology Studies
EHS 207.course_description: Introduction to methods of structuring toxicology experiments and analyzing data, including experimental design, data distributions, sample sizes, hypothesis testing, linear regression, analysis of variance, multiple comparison testing, and non-parametric tests.

EHS 212.course_description: The principles and practice of laboratory inhalation toxicology.  Topics include aerosols, gases, respiratory tract structure and function, lung defenses, aerosol deposition exposure techniques, characterization of exposure atmospheres, experimental designs, animal models, and regulations and guidelines.

EHS 220.course_description: Analysis of responsibilities toxicologists have in industry, including product safety, generating material safety, data sheets, animal testing, ecotoxicological testing, risk/hazard communication, and assisting industrial hygienists and occupational physicians; emphasis on interdisciplinary nature of industrial toxicology and communication skills.

EHS 264.course_description: Convergence of agents (chemical, physical, biological, or psychosocial) in environment can emerge as diseases influenced by social, political, and economic factors, allowing them to become rooted in society. How these agents from various spheres come together and impact human health.

EHS 269.course_description: Emission of air pollutants into the atmosphere, physical and meteorological processes that affect transport, and influence on global warming. Concepts of how and where people are most exposed, and how exposures and health effects differ in developed and developing regions.

EHS 275.course_description: Surveys the general principles, basic mathematical methods, and practices of environmental modeling and human health risk assessment. Topics include advection-dispersion models, risk management, and risk perception. Students conduct an original risk assessment as a final group project.

EHS 290.course_description: With consent from a faculty member who will supervise the program, a student may receive credit for individual study in some area of toxicology, culminating in the completion of a scholarly paper on the subject.

EHS 294.course_description: Focus on theory and research in health psychology as applied to major acute, chronic, and occupational health problems. Adopting the biopsychosocial model of health, emphasis is on understanding and influencing how biology, behavior, and the environment influence health and illness.

EHS 297.course_description: Discussions with clinical and research faculty in environmental toxicology and occupational medicine on current toxicology problems in the workplace and critical review of current publications in the field.

EHS 298.course_description: Presentation and discussion of current research problems and issues by students, postdoctoral fellows, faculty, and guests, covering the broad research and policy areas of environmental health sciences.

EHS 299.course_description: Research work for the M.S. thesis or Ph.D. dissertation.

BIOCHEM 200A.course_description: Individual research under the supervision of a professor.

BIOCHEM 200B.course_description: Individual research under the supervision of a professor.

BIOCHEM 200C.course_description: Individual research under the supervision of a professor.

BIOCHEM 200R.course_name: Research in Biological Chemistry for First-Year Students
BIOCHEM 200R.course_description: Independent research within the laboratories of graduate training faculty in the Department of Biological Chemistry for first-year Ph.D. students.

BIOCHEM 202A.course_description: Study within a laboratory group including research and journal presentations.

BIOCHEM 202B.course_description: Study within a laboratory group including research and journal presentations.

BIOCHEM 202C.course_description: Study within a laboratory group including research and journal presentations.

BIOCHEM 207.course_description: Literature-based discussion of molecular principles in genetics and functional genomics, with focus on cancer and stem cell biology.

BIOCHEM 210A.course_description: Covers the following topics from a biomedical perspective: protein and nucleic acid biochemistry, carbohydrates, lipids, amino acids, purines and pyrimidines, genome structure, molecular mechanisms of development, and signal transduction.

BIOCHEM 215.course_description: Introduction to using the mouse in contemporary biomedical research. The biology and development of the laboratory mouse, methods for manipulation of the mouse genome and embryos, and examples of application of these methods to understand mammalian development and homeostasis.

BIOCHEM 217.course_description: Covers theories and empirical research concerning the evolutionary origins of human behaviors and their variations. An interdisciplinary course emphasizing both evolutionary psychology (e.g., mating strategies, kinship, and parenting) and molecular evolution (i.e., evolution of genes for various behaviors).

BIOCHEM 225.course_description: Focuses on the role of chromatin/nuclear structure organization (histone and DNA modification, chromatin remodeling, higher order chromatin structure and nuclear organization) on gene regulation, DNA replication and repair, relevant to development, metabolism, learning and memory, and human disease.

BIOCHEM 291.course_description: Student research-based colloquium covering current topics in gene organization and expression, cell cycle and differentiation, DNA repair, checkpoint control, and the physical, chemical, and biological properties of macromolecules. Students are encouraged to read critically and analyze recent literature.

BIOCHEM 292A.course_description: Small group meetings for graduate students to practice scientific writing, debate, and presentation skills.

BIOCHEM 292B.course_description: Small group meetings for graduate students to practice scientific writing, debate, and presentation skills.

BIOCHEM 292C.course_description: Small group meetings for graduate students to practice scientific writing, debate, and presentation skills.

EAS 15C.course_description: Introduces students to major themes in Chinese literature and culture through the close reading, discussion, and analysis of selected texts in English translation.

EAS 15J.course_description: Introduces students to major themes in Japanese literature and culture through the close reading, discussion, and analysis of selected texts in English translation.

EAS 15K.course_description: Introduces students to major themes in Korean literature and culture through the close reading, discussion, and analysis of selected texts in English translation.

EAS 20.course_description: An introduction to Asian religions (Hinduism, Buddhism, Confucianism, Taoism, Shamanism) including both elite doctrinal aspects and forms of more popular religiosity.

EAS 40.course_name: Topics in East Asian Popular Culture
EAS 40.course_description: Selected topics in the popular cultural traditions of East Asia designed to introduce students both to problems in situating culture in a specific time and place and to contemporary theories of popular culture and their application to East Asian contexts.

EAS 55.course_description: Interdisciplinary courses organized each year around a broad theme designed to introduce students to the cultures of East Asia. Topical organization of courses addresses issues that have been of importance historically and are reshaping East Asia today.

EAS H84.course_description: Traveling East/West presents a wide range of travel writings by Chinese, Indian, and Euro-American authors in which they contemplate the complexities of cross-cultural encounters and how knowledge about others and knowledge of ourselves are closely intertwined.

EAS 110.course_name: Topics in Chinese Literature and Society
EAS 110.course_description: Studies in Chinese texts in their social and cultural context(s). Conducted in English.

EAS 116.course_description: Selected topics in the religions of East Asia, e.g., Buddhism, Daoism, Shintô, Christianity, popular religions.

EAS 117.course_description: Selected topics in the philosophies of East Asia, e.g., Yoga, Buddhism, Vedanta, Confucianism, Taoism, and Shinto.

EAS 120.course_name: Topics in Japanese Literature and Society
EAS 120.course_description: Studies in Japanese texts in their social and cultural context(s). Conducted in English.

EAS 123.course_description: An overview of the linguistic features of modern Japanese. Provides students with a systematic introduction to the nature and characteristics of the language.

EAS 126.course_description: In-depth examination of selected topics in the linguistics of East Asian languages, including Chinese, Japanese, Korean, and Vietnamese.

EAS 130.course_name: Topics in Korean Society and Culture
EAS 130.course_description: Studies of the social and cultural forces that affect the lives of the Koreans, including those in the United States. Considers traditional values and contemporary issues within a historical framework.

EAS 140.course_name: Topics in Korean Literature and Society
EAS 140.course_description: Studies in Korean texts in their social and cultural context(s). Conducted in English.

EAS 150.course_name: Topics in East Asian Literature in Translation
EAS 150.course_description: East Asian literary works in translation. Taught in English.

EAS 155.course_name: Topics in Cultural Studies in East Asia
EAS 155.course_description: Interdisciplinary and theoretical introduction to issues in cultural studies that are pertinent to the study of East Asia. All readings in English.

EAS 160.course_description: Study of East Asian cinema from historical, theoretical, and comparative perspectives. Taught in English.

EAS 170.course_name: Topics in Gender in East Asia
EAS 170.course_description: Explores the construction of gender in East Asian cultures and literatures. Pays close attention to the specificity of historical, cultural, and literary contexts of East Asia as it investigates various theoretical and critical perspectives on gender and sexuality.

EAS 190.course_description: Specialized courses dealing with primary sources; required reports and papers. Each colloquium reflects the instructor's intellectual interest and is conducted as a discussion group. Limited to 15 students.

EAS 192W.course_description: Analysis of a literary or cultural topic or problem through research and writing of two short and one long research paper for a minimum of 4,000 total words. Seminar follows EAS 190; related to the colloquium's subject.

EAS 199.course_description: Investigation of special topics through directed reading in translation. Paper required.

EAS 216.course_description: Selected topics in the religions of East Asia, e.g., Buddhism, Daoism, Shintô, Islam, shamanism.

EAS 220.course_name: Topics in East Asian Cultural Studies
EAS 220.course_description: Seminar, with topics varying from year to year. Research paper required.

EAS 225.course_name: Topics in East Asian Applied Linguistics
EAS 225.course_description: In-depth examination of selected topics in applied linguistics, with a particular emphasis on language acquisition and language pedagogy.

EAS 260.course_description: An examination of the possibilities of East Asian cinematic narrative. Possible topics: cinematic history; cinema in popular culture; comparisons with literary texts; major auteurs. Emphasis on technical as well as on thematic aspects. Includes readings in film theory.

EAS 290.course_description: Directed research on topic determined in consultation with faculty member. A term paper or project is required.

EAS 299.course_description: Dissertation research for students who are advanced to doctoral candidacy.

DRAMA 10.course_description: An interactive introduction to the world of theatre that serves to develop an appreciation of theatrical arts, to establish an awareness of landmarks within the performance history, and to create an understanding of the collaborative roles and departments that exist.

DRAMA 11.course_name: The Rock and Roll Spectacle Show
DRAMA 11.course_description: A thorough overview to the development and cultural significance of the Rock 'n' Roll Spectacle show. Focus on historical and recent developments of the spectacle show, trends in the aesthetics of the field, and various sub-genres.

DRAMA 12.course_description: An interactive and thorough overview of 21st century music theatre. Develops an appreciation and awareness of the contemporary musical on stage today, current trends in the development of new music theatre work, and the art form’s global expansion.

DRAMA 13.course_description: Food is the ambassador of cultures. The journey of food maps the history of human civilization. Examines feature films, documentaries, shorts, and writings on food, and analyzes the geopolitics, economics, migration, culture, performativity, and power of food.

DRAMA 14.course_description: Explores major movements in the history of rock 'n' roll in terms of performance, not virtuosity necessarily of the performers as musicians, rather as performances of aesthetics in modes of embodied ideology, iconoclastic spectacle, mixed media fashion, and subcultural formation.

DRAMA 15.course_description: Exposes students to what is most current in the world of performance and theatre.  Begins with a series of lectures on the idea of performance, and the various theories that frame it.

DRAMA 16.course_description: Culture, aesthetics, and ideology (combined in the concept "subculture") work to fashion social identities. Using theories and methodologies of performance studies, with an emphasis on American culture, explores why and how culture is reinforced through performance.

DRAMA 20A.course_description: A three-quarter foundation series exploring the rich depth of theatre, drama, and other genres of performance across a wide variety of worldwide forms, for performer and audience.

DRAMA 20B.course_description: A three-quarter foundation series exploring the rich depth of theatre, drama, and other genres of performance across a wide variety of worldwide forms, for performer and audience.

DRAMA 20C.course_description: A three-quarter foundation series exploring the rich depth of theatre, drama, and other genres of performance across a wide variety of worldwide forms, for performer and audience.

DRAMA 22.course_description: An introduction to Applied Improvisation (AI), the improvisational mindset, the current trends and historic uses of AI, and concepts and techniques from improvised theatre that can help individuals achieve their goals beyond creating comedy.

DRAMA 30A.course_description: Focuses on Stanislavski-based terminology and technique through theatre exercises and improvisation. The first part of a one-year series in basic acting technique and discipline.

DRAMA 30B.course_description: Focuses on scene work and character development. The second part of a one-year series in basic acting technique and discipline.

DRAMA 30C.course_description: Focuses on monologues, auditions, callbacks, and the profession of acting. The third part of a one-year series in basic acting technique and discipline.

DRAMA 34.course_description: A studio course in fundamentals of stretch, strength, and alignment; exploring spatial awareness and physical control through mime isolations, techniques, and related improvisation.

DRAMA 35.course_description: An introductory course in voice and speech for actors, combining the body-based approach to voice developed by Fitzmaurice, and speech work of Knight and Thompson. Designed for the needs of actors and is not a public speaking course.

DRAMA 40A.course_description: The development of Western Drama, concentrating on the drama’s intellectual, social, and artistic foundations. About 10 plays and supplementary critical material are read each quarter. Greek Drama through Shakespeare.

DRAMA 40B.course_description: The development of Western Drama, concentrating on the drama’s intellectual, social, and artistic foundations. About 10 plays and supplementary critical material are read each quarter. Restoration Drama through Ibsen.

DRAMA 40C.course_description: The development of Western Drama, concentrating on the drama’s intellectual, social, and artistic foundations. About 10 plays and supplementary material are read each quarter. Contemporary Drama. Post Naturalistic theatre.

DRAMA 50A.course_description: Introduction to the process and procedures employed by the costume designer for the theatre. The elements of design are discussed in the context of character development, historical period, and style. Exercises extend to drawing, rendering, and investigation of human proportions.

DRAMA 50B.course_description: Introduction to the principles and practice of scenic design. Weekly problems include research into various periods and styles of production with an emphasis on the conceptual idea. Perspective drawing, rendering, and model building are covered in studio exercises and assignments.

DRAMA 50C.course_description: Introduction to the principles, theories, and equipment employed by the lighting designer for the stage.  Areas of investigation include history, technology, and script analysis. Detailed studio attention is given to the theory and practice of design.

DRAMA 50D.course_description: Principles, theories, equipment use, and terminology employed by the sound designer for the stage. Areas of study include history, technology, and script analysis.  Focuses on the theory and practice of design.

DRAMA 50E.course_description: A basic study of theatrical, dance, and opera stage management practices, forms, and methods, from first script reading to closing night.  Opportunity to observe professionals at work in regional and touring situations as available.

DRAMA 60.course_description: Nurtures a greater appreciation for the stage manager and his or her process, and supports students who are interested in pursuing a career in professional stage management.

DRAMA 65.course_description: Basic vocal technique and characterization of musical theatre repertoire explored.

DRAMA 80.course_description: Introduction to comprehensive directing process from pre-production to opening. Focus on fundamental skills: analysis, staging, action, actor coaching, and elements of design. Skills applied to scripted theatrical material. Develop a language for commenting on theatrical production. Attending and critiquing productions.

DRAMA 100.course_description: Rehearsal and performance in a faculty-directed.

DRAMA 101A.course_description: The production courses are offered to give students the opportunity to participate in departmental productions. Students engage in the production and construction of designed work as well as its applied execution during performance.

DRAMA 101B.course_description: The production courses are offered to give students the opportunity to participate in departmental productions. Students engage in the production and construction of designed work as well as its applied execution during performance.

DRAMA 101C.course_description: The production courses are offered to give students the opportunity to participate in departmental productions. Students engage in the production and construction of designed work as well as its applied execution during performance.

DRAMA 101D.course_description: The production courses are offered to give students the opportunity to participate in departmental productions. Students engage in the production and construction of designed work as well as its applied execution during performance.

DRAMA 101E.course_description: The production courses are offered to give students the opportunity to participate in departmental productions. Students engage in the production and construction of designed work as well as its applied execution during performance.

DRAMA 101S.course_description: The production courses are offered to give students the opportunity to participate in departmental productions. Students engage in the production and construction of designed work as well as its applied execution during performance.

DRAMA 103.course_description: Courses include Medieval and Tudor Drama, Elizabethan and Jacobean Drama, Shakespeare, Restoration and 18th Century Drama, Modern British Drama, Modern American Drama, Tragedy, and Comedy.

DRAMA 103W.course_description: Courses include Medieval and Tudor Drama, Elizabethan and Jacobean Drama, Shakespeare, Restoration and Eighteenth-Century Drama, Modern British Drama, Modern American Drama, Tragedy, and Comedy.

DRAMA 109.course_name: Special Topics in Theory and Criticism
DRAMA 109.course_description: Discussion of recent major trends and ideas in critical theory, concentrating on in-depth readings and lectures in particular facets of theory and criticism: Derrida, Butler, Lacan, Deleuze, and others.

DRAMA 109W.course_name: Special Topics in Theory and Criticism
DRAMA 109W.course_description: Discussion of recent major trends and ideas in critical theory, concentrating on in-depth readings and lectures in particular facets of theory and criticism: Derrida, Butler, Lacan, Deleuze, and others.

DRAMA 110.course_description: Designed to introduce students to various classical traditions-early Greek and Roman theatres, to be sure, but also, by way of comparison, the classical traditions of non-European cultures.

DRAMA 110W.course_description: Designed to introduce students to various classical traditions-early Greek and Roman theatres, to be sure, but also, by way of comparison, the classical traditions of non-European cultures.

DRAMA 112W.course_name: Special Topics in Early Modern and Neoclassical Theatre
DRAMA 112W.course_description: Investigates aspects of European theatre and culture in the sixteenth, seventeenth, and eighteenth centuries; individual courses may focus on specific topics within this broad expanse.

DRAMA 116.course_description: Looks at the various trends and conventions of theatres in the nineteenth century, both Euro-American and beyond, paying special attention to the culture and political milieu within which these various traditions appeared.

DRAMA 116W.course_description: Looks at the various trends and conventions of theatres in the nineteenth century, both Euro-American and beyond, paying special attention to the culture and political milieu within which these various traditions appeared.

DRAMA 118.course_name: Special Topics in Modern and Contemporary Drama
DRAMA 118.course_description: An investigation into the many forms and permutations of modern (1880-1945), and contemporary (since 1945) drama, paying special attention to the historical and philosophical interpretations of text and performance.

DRAMA 118W.course_name: Special Topics in Modern and Contemporary Drama
DRAMA 118W.course_description: An investigation into the many forms and permutations of modern (1880-1945), and contemporary (since 1945) drama, paying special attention to the historical and philosophical interpretations of text and performance.

DRAMA 121.course_description: An introduction to some of the major traditional theatrical forms and dramatic texts from India, China, and Japan.  Other than dramatic texts (in English translation), attention is also paid to theory, history, and performance styles of traditional Asian theatre.

DRAMA 122.course_description: An introduction to the history and development of Asian American theatre and drama. Besides play analysis, special attention is also paid to the history and politics of Asian American identity and experience, as well as to aspects of theatrical performance.

DRAMA 123.course_description: A study of the history, culture, aesthetics, and literature of various traditional performing arts and their connections to the contemporary multicultural society.

DRAMA 126.course_description: A critical investigation of films and plays written by African Americans, with emphasis on dramaturgical and cinematic strategies, individual and collective representation, and the legacy of African American political struggle.

DRAMA 126W.course_description: A critical investigation of films and plays written by African Americans, with emphasis on dramaturgical and cinematic strategies, individual and collective representation, and the legacy of African American political struggle.

DRAMA 129.course_description: Addresses particular issues in theatre and performance that typically lie outside of regular course offerings. May address such issues as the theatre of the Avant Garde, performing gender, transversality and performance, body art, installation and performance art, among other topics.

DRAMA 129W.course_description: Addresses particular issues in theatre and performance that typically lie outside of regular course offerings. May address such issues as the theatre of the Avant Garde, performing gender, transversality and performance, body art, installation and performance art, among other topics.

DRAMA 130.course_description: Rehearsal and presentation of scenes from contemporary material. Focus on connection with scene partner, playing actions, and text analysis. Introduction to the credibility and theatricality of characterization and style.

DRAMA 132A.course_description: Completion of a full-length play or its equivalent; discussion of student writing and of relevant literary texts.

DRAMA 134.course_name: Studio for Advanced Movement for Actors
DRAMA 134.course_description: Studio course in conditioning and partnering techniques to the practice of contact improvisation. Contact improvisation is explored and applied in scene study.

DRAMA 135.course_description: Advanced acting in specialized areas including acting for the camera: situation comedy; commercials; auditioning and industry preparation; Shakespeare; Molière; Chekov; improvisation; advanced movement and voice and speech for the actor; self-starting; stage combat; repertory acting, singing; comedy; clowning; and masks.

DRAMA 136.course_description: An acting class exclusive to the students in the B.F.A. in Music Theatre program.

DRAMA 142.course_description: A workshop in audition technique and song interpretation.

DRAMA 143A.course_description: Scene study and song repertoire examined by era for the advanced Music Theatre student. 1800s-1940.

DRAMA 143B.course_description: Scene study and song repertoire examined by era for the advanced Music Theatre student. 1940s-1970s.

DRAMA 143C.course_description: Scene study and song repertoire examined by era for the advanced Music Theatre student. 1970's-present.

DRAMA 144.course_description: A performance class concentrating on role building. Work culminates with in-class performances of abbreviated versions of musicals.

DRAMA 145.course_description: Private weekly voice lessons for the advanced Music Theatre student.

DRAMA 146.course_description: Class preparation for the New York Satellite Program (NYSP) - an immersion experience in New York City for the musical theatre performer.

DRAMA 148A.course_description: A survey of the influential artists who produce, write, direct, and perform on America's musical stages. Surveys 1800s-1960s.

DRAMA 148B.course_description: A survey of the influential artists who produce, write, direct, and perform on America's musical stages. Surveys 1970s-present.

DRAMA 149.course_description: A musicianship class introducing basic musical terminology, theory, and sight singing skills.

DRAMA 150.course_description: Studio instruction in pattern making, draping, millinery, and construction techniques.

DRAMA 157.course_description: Provides an opportunity for students to pursue stage lighting composition in a studio atmosphere.  Laboratory practice includes weekly exercises in style and genre. Emphasis is placed on the realization of conceptual ideas.

DRAMA 158.course_description: Examines the various functions of scenery and costume: locale, historical period, mood, and atmosphere, with special assignments in each area. Discussion of problems in scenic metaphors and visualization, emphasizing techniques of planning and presentation (e.g., floor plans, models, and rendering).

DRAMA 164A.course_description: A study of the development of dress and the influence of cultural factors on clothing from the time of Egyptians to Early Baroque.

DRAMA 164B.course_description: A study of the development of dress and the influence of cultural factors on clothing from late Baroque to World War I.

DRAMA 176.course_description: A form and analysis seminar discussing the libretto and score of landmark musicals.

DRAMA 177.course_description: A song coaching class culminating in a song recital or showcase. Each quarter will feature a different composer, lyricist, or musical style.

DRAMA 180.course_description: Reading and analysis of theories and critical approaches to contemporary theatre: Brecht, Artaud, and others who have contributed to the form and idea of the modern theatre. Writing of assigned exercises in dramatic criticism.

DRAMA 180W.course_description: Reading and analysis of theories and critical approaches to contemporary theatre:  Brecht, Artaud, and others who have contributed to the form and idea of the modern theatre. Writing of assigned exercises in dramatic criticism.

DRAMA 182A.course_description: Advanced beginner and intermediate dance training including musical theatre, ballet, jazz and contemporary modern techniques and repertoire.  Body conditioning is also a major component of the course.

DRAMA 182B.course_description: Advanced beginner and intermediate dance training including musical theatre, ballet, jazz and contemporary modern techniques and repertoire.  Body conditioning is also a major component of the course.

DRAMA 183A.course_description: Intermediate and advanced dance training including musical theatre, ballet, jazz and contemporary modern techniques and repertoire.  Body conditioning is also a major component of the course.

DRAMA 183B.course_description: Intermediate and advanced dance training including musical theatre, ballet, jazz and contemporary modern techniques and repertoire.  Body conditioning is also a major component of the course.

DRAMA 184.course_description: The principles of stage directing, covering the director's functions in the areas of interpretation, composition, coaching, and styling a theatrical production. Directing exercises and projects; the final project is the preparation of a hypothetical proposal for a play production.

DRAMA 185.course_description: A seminar in directorial organization and research.  Student prepares a textual and dramaturgical analysis, a production timetable, and a hypothetical production book of an assigned play.

DRAMA 190.course_description: New York Satellite Program acting classes taught by guest faculty in New York.

DRAMA 191.course_description: New York Satellite Program dance classes in ballet, tap, jazz, and musical theatre styles taught by guest faculty in New York.

DRAMA 192.course_description: New York Satellite Program private and group lessons in musical theatre singing taught by guest faculty in New York.

DRAMA 193.course_description: New York Satellite Program rehearsals and public, staged readings of original musicals in New York.

DRAMA 194.course_description: New York Satellite Program follow-up classes and performances back on Irvine campus upon the return from New York.

DRAMA 195.course_description: Advanced dance classes in specialized areas including the dance styles of a choreographer (de Mille, Fosse, Robbins, Tune, Stroman), genre (tap, ballroom, jazz, swing, hip-hop), or in musical theatre choreography.

DRAMA 198.course_description: For students who are involved in the Director Class Projects at UCI as actors, directors, designers, stage managers and their assistants. M.F.A. Directors and the Head of Directing (HoD) supervise the projects.

DRAMA 199.course_description: Independent theatre projects with Drama faculty.

DRAMA 200.course_description: Work in graduate studio taken in tandem with graduate studios in stage voice (DRAMA 201), stage speech (DRAMA 202), and stage movement (DRAMA 203).

DRAMA 201.course_description: Graduate studio in vocal production for actors.

DRAMA 202.course_description: Graduate studio in speech for actors.

DRAMA 203.course_description: Work in graduate studio: stage movement taken in tandem with nine graduate studios in acting (DRAMA 200), voice (DRAMA 201), speech (DRAMA 202), and voice/movement dynamics (DRAMA 206).

DRAMA 219.course_description: Various topics such as Shakespeare, comedy, Molière, improvisation, Kabuki, television acting.

DRAMA 225.course_description: A seminar on the major teaching systems in the dramatic arts with particular attention to professional arts training. Required prior to applying for Teaching Assistantships in studio areas.

DRAMA 240.course_description: Various projects depending on student’s concentration (acting, design, musical theatre, directing).

DRAMA 241.course_description: Learning how to teach voice lessons and coach musical theatre singing. Experiences include both private voice lessons and observing the lessons given to the B.F.A./Music Theatre students.

DRAMA 242.course_description: Private conducting instruction to develop freedom of movement/expression, baton technique, ear training, and tempo memory for both rehearsal and performance situations in musical theatre.

DRAMA 243.course_description: A form and analysis seminar discussing the libretto and score of landmark musicals.

DRAMA 244.course_description: Examines the practice, place, and theory of dramaturgy.  Explores plays in terms of how they work: dramatic form and structure, historical context, and more. Study includes dramaturgy as a theatrical practice.

DRAMA 246A.course_description: Musically directing scenes from musicals of various time periods. Features works from the late 19th and early 20th centuries, including songwriters Gilbert and Sullivan, Irving Berlin, George Gershwin, Rodgers and Hart, and Cole Porter.

DRAMA 246B.course_description: Musically directing scenes from musicals of various time periods. Features works from the middle of the 20th century including songwriters Rodgers and Hammerstein, Lerner and Loewe, Julie Styne, Kander and Ebb, and Jerry Herman.

DRAMA 246C.course_description: Musically directing scenes from musicals of various time periods.  Features works from the late 20th and early 21st centuries including songwriters Stephen Sondheim, Andrew Lloyd Webber, Stephen Schwartz, Flaherty and Ahrens, and Jeanine Tesori.

DRAMA 247.course_description: Musically directing abridged versions of musicals from various time periods and genres.

DRAMA 248A.course_description: A survey of the influential artists who produce, write, direct, and perform on America's musical stages. Surveys 1800s-1960s.

DRAMA 248B.course_description: A survey of the influential artists who produce, write, direct, and perform on America's musical stages. Surveys 1970s-present.

DRAMA 249.course_description: Various musical direction activities including the vocal direction, accompanying, and conducting of musical theatre performances.

DRAMA 251A.course_description: Seeks to create greater understanding in the roots and theories of theatrical models, aesthetics, action vs. reaction of differing thoughts in theatrical doctrine, and art, architecture, music, and fashion that contributed to the style and practice of theatre.

DRAMA 251B.course_description: Seeks to create greater understanding in the roots and theories of theatrical models, aesthetics, action vs. reaction of differing thoughts in theatrical doctrine, and art, architecture, music, and fashion that contributed to the style and practice of theatre.

DRAMA 251C.course_description: Seeks to create greater understanding in the roots and theories of theatrical models, aesthetics, action vs. reaction of differing thoughts in theatrical doctrine, and art, architecture, music, and fashion that contributed to the style and practice of theatre.

DRAMA 254.course_description: Studio exercises and projects in stage management.

DRAMA 255.course_description: Projects, lectures, and critical discussion in costume, scenery, lighting, and sound design.

DRAMA 256.course_name: Survival and Professional Practice in Design
DRAMA 256.course_description: Provides an in-depth examination of business skills needed to survive as a theatrical designer. Required 'Bridge' course in the Design MFA programs, relevant to all disciplines.

DRAMA 257A.course_description: Development of thesis project with focus on organization, research, timeline, and execution.

DRAMA 257B.course_description: Development of thesis project with focus on organization, research, timeline, and execution.

DRAMA 257E.course_description: Development of thesis topic with focus on organization, research, timeline, and execution.

DRAMA 258.course_description: A multi-skill level course in drawing technique focusing on skills essential to stage designers including line, proportion, perspective and creating dynamic compositions. Focus will primarily be in figure drawing but may include still-life, landscape, and architectural drawings. Materials fee.

DRAMA 259.course_description: Exposes students to a wider range of theatrical practitioners, theories, and topics through guest lecturers, special projects, and cross-disciplinary dialogue.

DRAMA 260A.course_description: A studio course in costume rendering for the theatre using computer image manipulation. Instruction in compositing and painting techniques and performance design conventions.

DRAMA 260B.course_description: A studio course in textile design using digital printing and embossing techniques. Instruction in state-of-the-art software and output manipulation for artistic expression.

DRAMA 261.course_description: A studio course in scenic or costume rendering for the theatre using the computer for drawing/painting through the use of the digital pen/tablet.

DRAMA 262.course_description: A studio course in CAD's 2D drafting and 3D modeling capabilities for theatrical design. Instruction in state-of-the-art software for 2D and 3D object creation and theatrical presentation conventions.

DRAMA 263.course_description: A studio course in theatrical design through 3d modeling on computer and use of state-of-the-art rendering software. Instruction emphasizes collaborative design process through the use of scenic designer/lighting designer teams for all projects.

DRAMA 264.course_description: A studio course in the various graphic methods employed by lighting designers in the theatre.  Projects include manual and CAD techniques for Light Plot and Paperwork creation.

DRAMA 265.course_description: A studio course in theatrical design and architectural lighting design on the computer.  Instruction in state-of-the-art software for 2D object creation.  Theatrical and architectural standards implemented in performance design.

DRAMA 266.course_description: Comprehensive tutorial on digital audio including hard disk recording, editing, data compression, and ethernet audio distribution.  Focus is on recording, editing, and delivery of audio as used by the sound designer in the digital domain.

DRAMA 267.course_name: Digital Design: Creating Sounds from Scratch
DRAMA 267.course_description: The process of analyzing sounds for their core timbral components and using that data to create new sounds - from realistic to fantastic - by means of digital manipulation.

DRAMA 271.course_description: An intensive, project-based seminar for exploring relationships between sound and sight.  Synesthesia, creative intent vs. audience perception, and sound/movement are typical of the many topics to be explored.  A series of creative projects are assigned and critiqued in peer review.

DRAMA 272.course_description: A concept-to-opening study of the process of designing sound systems for musicals and live/touring sound.  Special attention given to the paperwork and documentation required to package, build, and mix these shows.

DRAMA 277.course_description: Exploration of the many variables that affect (and effect) the audio chain.  Perceiving and understanding these parameters unlocks the art of controlling sound and stylizing cues.  Also includes the process of equalizing/aligning sound systems and the art of audio mastering.

DRAMA 279.course_description: An in-depth investigation into sound design for the theatre. Special emphasis is placed on text analysis, design conception, content creation, content delivery, and design organization. Class projects include creating paper designs and paperwork for different texts.

DRAMA 280A.course_description: Student exercises in the techniques and implementation of costume design.

DRAMA 280B.course_description: Student exercises in the techniques and implementation of scenic design.

DRAMA 280C.course_description: Student exercises in the techniques and implementation of lighting design.

DRAMA 280D.course_description: Student exercises in the techniques and implementation of sound design.

DRAMA 282.course_description: Using computers and dedicated hardware to cue, control or automate sound, scenery, and lighting for live performance and themed entertainment applications.

DRAMA 290.course_name: Dramatic Literature and Theatre History Prior to 1900
DRAMA 290.course_description: Studies in selected areas of dramatic literature and theatre history prior to 1900. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

DRAMA 291.course_name: Dramatic Literature and Theatre History, 1900 to Present
DRAMA 291.course_description: Studies in selected areas of dramatic literature and theatre history, 1900 to present. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

DRAMA 292.course_description: Studies in selected areas of cultural and critical theory. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

DRAMA 295.course_description: An arranged internship at the South Coast Repertory Theatre, or other equity theatre company, for qualifying M.F.A. students. A stipend and equity points are provided by the theatre company.

DRAMA 297.course_description: Requires doctoral students to identify two plays from the Drama Department's season to work as dramaturges. Students write a Dramaturgy Booklet recording their research and interactions with director, actors, and the design team. Students will work with doctoral faculty.

DRAMA 299.course_description: Independent or collaborative practical work combined with strong research components, such critical analysis, fieldwork, or theorization. Requires Ph.D. faculty as mentors.

COM LIT 3.course_name: Just Reading: Developing the Reading Experience
COM LIT 3.course_description: Develops the reading experience apart from writing. Develops tools for sustained attention in reading practice across a wide range of genres and media from across the globe. Students learn to appreciate elements of reading experience such as attention and perplexity.

COM LIT 8.course_description: Readings in English and in English translation on such topics as love, war, cities, travel writing, politics, fantasy and science fiction, violence.

COM LIT 9.course_description: Various themes and forms of literary and cultural production within a multicultural framework, including African American, Asian American, Chicano/Latino, and Native American literatures and cultures.

COM LIT 10.course_description: Introduction to texts from across the globe and from different historical periods.  Readings in English and English translation.

COM LIT 60A.course_description: An introduction to the comparative study of literatures and cultures in a global context. Studies literary texts and other media across the borders of various cultures, historical periods, and traditions. All texts are read in English translation.

COM LIT 60B.course_description: Introduction to theory and methods of literary and cultural criticism in a global context. Students read theoretical approaches to literature, culture, and ideas. Marx and Freud, e.g., may be studied alongside readings in narrative poetry, film, song lyrics, novel.

COM LIT 60C.course_description: Introduces students to a variety of cultural practices (literature, blogs, films, radio, comics) from across the globe. Focuses on the ways that context, genre, and medium (e.g., written, visual, oral) affect how these practices are produced, circulated, and received.

COM LIT 100A.course_description: Intensive study of national and regional cultural and literary traditions from across the globe, among them the literary and cultural production of the Middle East, Africa, Europe, the Americas, and Asia.

COM LIT 101W.course_description: Focuses on theories of translation and on how these theories help students understand the role of translation in the world. Students develop a critical vocabulary for discussing translation in multiple linguistic traditions and complete a final translation project.

COM LIT 102W.course_name: Comparative Studies in Literature and Theory

COM LIT 105.course_description: Treats the literatures and cultures of one or more minority groups in California and the United States, including African Americans, Asian Americans, Chicano/Latinos, and Native Americans, and their relations to other national literatures.

COM LIT 107.course_description: Explores topics such as colonialism and race, decolonization, pre- and postcoloniality, globalization, and the cultural dynamics of colonization and subjectivity.

COM LIT 121.course_description: Explores textual patterns, structures, and effects.  May include topics such as novel, hypertext, genre, reader responses, intertextuality.

COM LIT 123.course_description: Studies how texts interact across time and space in a global context. Uses concepts of influence, imitation, and parody, to ask, for example, how the Homeric epics can help us understand Caribbean novels and U.S. movies such as Troy.

COM LIT 130.course_description: Discusses the roles of differences such as race, class, gender, and sexuality in society, culture, and literature across the globe, covering topics such as theoretical and literary representations of queer sexuality, gender performance, critical race theory.

COM LIT 131.course_description: Discusses major psychoanalytic writings of Freud and others in connection with questions of culture.

COM LIT 132.course_description: Compares ideologies and systems, e.g., nationalism and fundamentalism, as they affect literature and culture in a global context.

COM LIT 140.course_description: Introduces a variety of ways of understanding cultural phenomena in relation to different power structures.  These cultural phenomena may include comics, film, literature, sports, music, festivals, telling stories, or eating out.

COM LIT 142.course_name: The Metropolis and Other Cultural Geographies
COM LIT 142.course_description: Examines the relationship between space and culture; cultural production in the city, suburb, and/or countryside; spaces in texts and artifacts (film, literature, comics, photographs) in a global context.

COM LIT 143.course_description: Explores literature and other arts and media in a global context. May include film and electronic media, fine arts, oral cultures, architecture, in an international framework.

COM LIT 144.course_description: Explores the relationship between literary texts and their historical and social contexts in an international framework. Courses may address, for example, literary and cultural expressions in social revolutions or the way literary texts talk back to medicine, religion, and anthropology.

COM LIT 150.course_description: The study of literary works in one or more genres in English translation.  May be a comparative study of works from several different original languages or a concentration on works from a single cultural/linguistic tradition.

COM LIT 160.course_description: Comparative analysis of contemporary film in languages other than English.

COM LIT 190W.course_name: Advanced Seminar in Comparative Literature and Theory
COM LIT 190W.course_description: Capstone seminar for the Comparative Literature major. Deepens understanding of the field through investigation of a special topic and a substantial research and writing project.

COM LIT 199.course_description: To be taken only when the materials to be studied lie outside the normal run of departmental offerings.

COM LIT 200A.course_name: History of Comparative Literature and Introduction to Methods and Theories of CL
COM LIT 200A.course_description: Seminar designed to introduce graduate students in Comparative Literature to the discipline of Comparative Literature.
